channel.title: Commercial Real Estate and Commercial Law
channel.description: Commercial Real Estate and Commercial Law

item.title: Tenant Shall Do This But Landlord Shall Do That
item.description:
Tenant Shall Do This But Landlord Shall Do That

If you are working on a lease or any other contract for that matter, one should really stop using the word "shall." With contracts, especially leases, shall has two different meanings. Shall has two different meanings, "must" or "will." One is a requirement, and one is a requirement or action that will be done in the future.

item.title: Severablity Clauses in Commercial Leases
item.description:
Severablity Clauses in Commercial Leases

Severability clauses are boilerplate these days, especially in commercial leases. Below is an example of the standard clause... The invalidity or unenforceability of any provisions of this Agreement shall not affect the validity or enforceability of any other provision of this Agreement, which shall remain in full force and effect.

item.title: Warranties and Representations
item.description:
Warranties and Representations

After Italian Cowboy Partners v. Prudential Insurance Company of America, future leases need to be updated to reflect the rulings on this case. In the case, Cowboys, a restaurant, sued the landlord for breach of warranty. The landlord said the location would be perfect for a restaurant.

item.title: The Art of Deal Making
item.description:
The Art of Deal Making

There are many ways that a deal dies. Time kills deals for one. Pride kills deals. Bargain hunting kills deals. And arguing over lease details can definitely kill a deal. It happens in commercial real estate transactions with regards to the battle of the leases.

item.title: The Art of Deal Making II
item.description:
The Art of Deal Making II

In the commercial real estate world, parties often negotiate through letters of intent (LOI). Usually, these are one to two pages in length and outline the major terms of a deal. Such terms include how much rent, the size of the space to lease and the length of the term.

item.title: Ready, Set, Go! Timing in Leases
item.description:
Ready, Set, Go! Timing in Leases

Time frames are crucial in leases. That's one of the benefits of having a simple, straight forward lease. It makes it easy to know when something happens. After all, the landlord certainly wants to know when they can start getting rent. The tenant certainly needs to know when they have to start paying rent.

item.title: Lease Renewals
item.description:
Lease Renewals

This will be the first part in a three part series. Part 2 here. Part 3 here. Now, most leases usually have a provision in a lease that looks something like this: At the end of this lease, the tenant may extend this lease for x months.

item.title: Will Sell Fruit, including Bananas, Oranges, Grapes, Pears and Plums.
item.description:
Will Sell Fruit, including Bananas, Oranges, Grapes, Pears and Plums.

There is often a lot of redundancy in leases and such redundancy can turn a great lease into a bad lease. Just look at the title of this post. The "including Bananas, Oranges, Grapes, Pears, and Plumbs" is completely redundant. Those are all different kinds of fruit.

item.title: Lease Renewals- A Tenant Perspective
item.description:
Lease Renewals- A Tenant Perspective

This is the second part of my three part series on lease renewals. Part 1 here. Part 3 here. As a tenant the best time to plan for your lease renewal is before you even sign the initial lease. At this time, you as the tenant have a much stronger negotiating position.

item.title: Remember, Time Costs Money
item.description:
Remember, Time Costs Money

Using a simple lease will probably increase the net worth of both landlord and tenant by saving time with lease negotiations. This can easily be demonstrated with two scenarios: Scenario 1: The tenant and the landlord have finally agreed to essential business terms through a month long back and forth negotiation.
